Excited to read this - congrats to you both!

On Tue, May 12, 2015 at 9:48 =
AM, Jeff Clune jclune@... [neat] <
neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:

>
>
=
> A huge congratulations to Ken and Joel for this book coming out!
>
>
> Be=
st regards,
> *Jeff Clune*
>
> Assistant Professor, Computer Science
> Dire=
ctor, Evolving Artificial Intelligence Lab <http://EvolvingAI.org>
> Univer=
sity of Wyoming
> jeffclune@...
> jeffclune.com
>
> On May 11, 2015, a=
t 11:05 PM, kstanley@... [neat] <
> neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
=
>
>
>
> Joel Lehman and I are pleased to announce the publication of our ne=
w book
> by Springer:
>
> Why Greatness Cannot Be Planned: The Myth of the =
Objective
>
> You can get it at Amazon:
> http://www.amazon.com/Why-Greatne=
ss-Cannot-Planned-Objective/dp/3319155237
>
>
> Or through Springer: http:/=
/www.springer.com/us/book/9783319155234
>
> As some of you know, Joel and I=
 have long thought that the implications of
> novelty search and non-object=
ive thinking in general extend far beyond only
> machine learning and evolu=
tionary computation.  From the way we as a
> society encourage innovation t=
o the interpretation of evolution in nature,
> the implications of the obje=
ctive paradox touch an enormous breadth of
> domains, including of course t=
he now-familiar algorithmic insights.  Our
> new book finally gives us the =
chance to weave all these disparate threads
> together into a single unifie=
d perspective.  As a rare example of
> algorithmic insights from AI leading=
 to a broader social and cultural
> critique, we hope you will find its mes=
sage inspiring and
> thought-provoking.   Of course we're always happy to h=
ear your thoughts as
> well.
>
> Here's the cover:
>
>
>
>
> Best,
>
>
> Ke=
n and Joel
>
>
>  
>

--001a11330192d8f2e70515febb35

<div style=3D"background-color:#ff=
f">
<span>=C2=A0</span>



    <div><p>Joel Lehman and I are pleased to ann=
ounce the publication of our new book by Springer:<br><br><span style=3D"fo=
nt-weight:bold">Why Greatness Cannot Be Planned: The Myth of the Objective<=
/span><br><br>You can get it at Amazon: <a rel=3D"nofollow" href=3D"http://=
www.amazon.com/Why-Greatness-Cannot-Planned-Objective/dp/3319155237" target=
=3D"_blank">http://www.amazon.com/Why-Greatness-Cannot-Planned-Objective/dp=
/3319155237</a></p><p>=C2=A0 <br></p>Or through Springer: <a rel=3D"nofollo=
w" href=3D"http://www.springer.com/us/book/9783319155234" target=3D"_blank"=
>http://www.springer.com/us/book/9783319155234</a><br><br>As some of you kn=
ow, Joel and I have long thought that the implications of novelty search an=
d non-objective thinking in general extend far beyond only machine learning=
 and evolutionary computation.=C2=A0 From the way we as a society encourage=
 innovation to the interpretation of evolution in nature, the implications =
of the objective paradox touch an enormous breadth of domains, including of=
 course the now-familiar algorithmic insights.=C2=A0 Our new book finally g=
ives us the chance to weave all these disparate threads together into a sin=
gle unified perspective.=C2=A0 As a rare example of algorithmic insights fr=
om AI leading to a broader social and cultural critique, we hope you will f=
ind its message inspiring and thought-provoking. =C2=A0 Of course we're=
 always happy to hear your thoughts as well. <br><br>Here's the cover:<=
br><div> =C2=A0<br></div><img src=3D"http://www.cs.ucf.edu/%7Ekstanley/cove=
r_hires_50pcnt.png" width=3D"150"><br><br><br><p><span>Best,</span></p><p><=
br><span></span></p><p><span>Ken and Joel<br></span></p><div><br></div>

  =
  </div>
     

    

</div>





</div></blockquote></div><br></span><p></=
p>

    </div>

>
